In spectroscopy, the 'absorbance' (also called 'optical density' [http://books.google.com/books?id=j7ol1TL5OZ8C&pg=PA79The Laser Guidebook, by
Jeff Hecht, p79] ) of a material is a logarithmic ratio of the radiation
falling upon a material, to the radiation transmitted through a
material. Mehta, A. [http://pharmaxchange.info/press/2012/04/ultraviolet-visible-uv-vis-
spectroscopy-%E2%80%93-derivation-of-beer-lambert-law/ UV-Visible Spectroscopy-
Derivation of Beer-Lambert Law] {{cite web |url=http://www.websters-online-
dictionary.org/ab/absorptance.html|title=Dictionary â Definition of
absorptance |publisher=Websters-online-dictionary.org |date= |accessdate=2011-11-
21}}  Absorbance measurements are often carried out in analytical
chemistry.

In physics, the term spectral'absorbance' is used interchangeably with
spectral'absorptance' or '[[absorptivity]]'. In this case it has a slightly
different meaning: the fraction of radiation absorbed at a specific wavelengths.
